results.title: Hoop culture
results.brief_description: Created in response to a class assignment to offer a visual interpretation of ‘cultural identity’, this short After Effects animation focuses itself on different aspects of the ‘hoop culture’ of amateur basketball around melbourne.

results.title: The Pier
results.brief_description: Short film shot 1990 on Super 8 Film of St Kilda Pier (burnt down 2003). Filmed early in the morning, the moody feel of the work is heightened by atmospheric soundtrack (added by ACMI) Captures the shared experience of a morning spent at this popular spot for St Kilda residents.

results.title: 4 Vertigo
results.brief_description:
Les LeVeque is a New York-based artist who has produced a number of videos and video installations exploring the cultural implications of technological change. Recently he has been making video works that use Hollywood classics as their starting point, transforming them into sensuous, hallucinatory works which aim to unveil the repressed representations that loiter inside so many ‘wholesome’ American classics. These include ‘2 Spellbound’ (1999), a reworking of Alfred Hitchcock’s ‘Spellbound’ (1945), and ‘Backwards Birth of a Nation’ (2000), in which D.W. Griffith’s 1915 feature film is reversed and re-edited into a 13-minute phantasm. LeVeque’s works have featured at the New York Video Festival, the Sundance Film Festival, the 2000 Whitney Biennial and the Pompidou Centre in Paris.

In ‘4 Vertigo’, Hitchcock’s 128-minute feature film ‘Vertigo’ has been processed anew by capturing one frame for every two seconds of the original movie. The condensed film was duplicated four times, shifting the horizontal or vertical orientation of the frame with each duplication so that the first image is right side up, the next is sideways, then upside down, then sideways, and finally right side up again. This is only evident when the video is examined frame by frame: played at normal speed the result is a stuttering kaleidoscopic engine that gives the viewer a nauseating yet thrilling sensation of physical and psychic
weightlessness. In LeVeque’s treatment the layered plot line and psychological depths of the Hitchcock original are overtaken by the patterns and rhythms of the new aesthetic centrifuge.

LeVeque states: ‘Building on the notion of obsessive looking, I wanted to transform the original movie into a spinning mandala to generate a sensuous viewing where the dramatic narrative becomes unstable and elusive, a viewing experience where the hypnosis of cinematic spectacle is articulated to such a physical degree that it engenders a consciousness of watching.’

results.title: Casting iron plow-shares
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mountain peoples of Central Asia”.
This film presents Tajik men of Afghanistan performing the several stages that shape, mould and cast, in wet sands, their iron plow-shares. It explains how over the centuries this ancient craft has achieved economy of action and perfect timing. No narration - traditional music accompaniament. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: Beard and bass
results.brief_description: An experimental short film about a bearded young man and a double bass. Clasping the instrument he tries to cross a street. Suddenly his attention is arrested by a girl whose charms he appreciates. She smiles at him and crosses the street. He stares at her and then realising suddenly that she has disappeared, he props up his double bass against the tree and disappears into the crowd. Music by George Dreyfus, edited by Peter Tammer.

results.title: November = Novembre
results.creator_credit: Robert Nichol, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A hundred and one lingering, luminous impressions of the month when the ripe fullness of the Canadian autumn wilts and the whole earth seems to settle into brooding calm. This is a cine-poem, reflecting the somber moods of November, the still, waiting separateness when the Canadian year dawdles, hangs back from the hour when the first snowfall will make all things even. But from the muted tones of the dying season emerges a new, stark beauty. Film without words. (Contains images of duck hunting and animial skinning that may offend some viewers.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Nichol, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Drink Deep
results.brief_description: Drink Deep is a lyrical vision of friendship, hidden secrets, and desires. Cohen uses several types of film image to add texture to the layered composition. Beautiful shades of grey, silver, black and blue echo the water, reminiscent of early photography and silverprints. Cohen says, “The piece was constructed primarily from footage Iâ€™d shot of skinnydippers at swimming holes in Georgia and rural Pennsylvania. Itâ€™s about water and memory and stories just submerged. It is also, in part, a response to thinking about censorship. I would say that Drink Deep is both unabashedly and deceptively romantic. Surface, flow, and undertow. What looks like paradise is always paradise lost.” Music composed by Stephen Vitiello and performed with Gabriel Cohen and Mary Wooten.

results.title: My shadow
results.brief_description:
Flat tyres, mystery calls. Cathy is being watched. Someone is following her, close as a shadow. Cathy tells her best friend. Heath already knows. The phone rings through the night. Is anyone listening?
A beautifully hand-drawn 2D animated narrative which captures the sense of frustration and fear when your life appears threatened by an unknown stalker and no-one out there is listening to your cries for help.

results.title: Project the right image
results.brief_description:
English production, NOT made by the Department of Agriculture.

Details hot to and how not to project a 16mm film using a social church gathering as the backdrop. Stars a bumbling projectionist and a priest who first do everything the wrong way and then do everything the correct way.

Comical (in a daggy way) throughout with good use of slapstick humour. Also contains an amusing, very dry voiceover.
